central_thesis: This Scroll of Set explores the philosophy and practice of Setian self-evolution (Xeper) through diverse lenses, including historical figures, mythological archetypes, psychological concepts, and magical theory. It emphasizes the individual's conscious act of becoming, distinct from external influences, and the practical application of these principles in both inner and outer worlds to achieve unique personal apotheosis and mastery.

structure_content.summary: Analyzes Merlin's life as an exemplary initiatory pattern for Remanifestation within Setians. Merlin's half-human, half-supernatural origin symbolizes the 'alien, non-natural seed of Set' within Elect. His magical power stems from integrating his inner feminine (dark goddess/fylgja) with his outer masculine nature, achieving wholeness. Setians can Remanifest this vision by recognizing their non-natural origins and polarizing psychic forces.
Notes the recognition of Kris Flippo and Robert Sloan to the Degree of Adept by Priests William D. Pridgen and Curtis A. Rowlett, and Priestess Marie Kelly, respectively.

Announces Volume II of The Jaguar, a newsletter from The Smoking Mirror Pylon focused on Aztec and Mayan Black Magic. It features articles on John Dee's 'shew stone' (Aztec smoking mirror), Tezcatlipoca's playful side, Aztec soulcraft, a ritual to awaken four virtues, and a poem invoking Tezcatlipoca's 'Night Axe.' The newsletter is presented as an entry point into Mesoamerican magical lore.

structure_content.chapter_title: [4] Satanism vs. Setian Philosophy (The Debate Continues)
structure_content.summary: Discusses the ongoing debate regarding the use of 'Satan' versus 'Set.' Argues that 'Satan' is acceptable intra-Temple but 'Setian' is necessary for clear external communication to avoid Christianized connotations. Quotes Dr. Aquino on conventional Satanism's dependency on God. Contends that identifying as 'Satanic' to the outside world loses credibility as Christianity declines, and true Dark Souls may be missed.

Explores the concept of Genius Loci (spirit of a place). Argues that traditional sacred sites may be 'drained' by tourism, advocating for discovering and creating *personal* magical energy sources, which are often hidden and 'find you.' Emphasizes internal ritualization for public sites, contrasting personal experience at the vibrant Bruchhauser Steine with the diminished Externsteine.

Reflects on personal and Æonic changes, introducing Jung's 'Number 1' (ego) and 'Number 2' (archetypal self). Relates these to Setian philosophy, with 'Horus' as the psychophysical complex and 'Set' as the core Essence/higher self. Achieving 'Samtaui' (harmony) between these aspects leads to becoming 'conscious, free-willed agents.' Views Set as the 'First Form of Isolate Intelligence' and 'Neter of neters.'

Explores Form, function, carrier, and resonance in Setian magic. Introduces 'triadic comprehension' as key to self-reference, allowing an 'I' (observer) to know both 'outside' and 'within.' Discusses Egyptian triads and their link to Æonic resonance, explaining higher-ordered phasing relationships (e.g., 1:8 ratio) and 'density' of energy. Connects extension to matter manifestation and retraction to spirit manifestation, clarifying Left-Hand Path principles.

Examines the Setian dilemma of public vs. covert practice. The author recounts personal transition from open display to a low-keyed approach in professional life, questioning if this is retreat or maturity. Concludes that respect for individual choices is paramount, and Xeper can occur regardless of public visibility. Mentions the author's work on a Black Magical grimoire, Liber Satanicus.

Analyzes music and sound as powerful magical tools, linking their mathematical precision to the Pentagram of Set as an 'aural gateway.' Describes music's role in creating subjective universes in ritual and the ability of electronically-synthesized music to evoke 'other-worldly' sounds. Proposes creating Setian-specific music. Concludes that human perception and creation of music are manifestations of the Gift of Set.

Defines 'Neheh' as the eternal future to be filled with Xeper deeds. Announces Don Webb as the third High Priest of Set, outlining his role in administration and synthesizing the Temple's essence. Discusses feminine aspects in Setianism through Set's 'three wives': Nepthys (goal, higher being), Anat (foresight, preparedness), and Astarte (Scarlet Woman, manifest 'dream date'), emphasizing 'conscious setting-free' from conventional feminine models.
Recommends 'Colors' magazine for its disturbing photography and world view, suggesting it can aid Xeper by changing one's perspective.

structure_content.chapter_title: [12] An Etymological and Philosophical Dissection of Magical Words
structure_content.summary: Provides technical definitions of core Setian terms: 'Essence' (vital core, fixed state), 'Escence' (process of becoming), 'Become' (movement towards desired state, translation of Xeper), 'Being' (quality of possessing existence), 'Come Into Being' (self traveling into manifested state, self-discovery), and 'Inspiration' (spirit, that which moves the intellect, producing action).
A poetic invocation exploring themes of dark ecstasy, vision, the 'Dark Runa,' the serpent (Uræus) rising to the crown, 'Come Into Being,' and the declaration 'The essence is mine.'
A poem invoking 'Nox, obsidian and gleaming' as 'Imperatrix' of the night, depicting her power over the day and her role in echoing ancient mysteries.

Reviews various music albums, including Erik Satie's piano works, Pelikan Daughters' synthscapes, Wolf Talk's nature sounds, Ordo Equitum Solis's Gothic pagan music, and Hildegard von Bingen's medieval drama. Notably highlights a Christian piece with a disruptive 'Satan' part, making it relevant to the Scroll's theme of antithesis.

structure_content.chapter_title: [16] The Two Worlds: Some Celtic Mythology
structure_content.summary: Compares Christian 'three aspects' of reality with Celtic 'two worlds' (ordinary and other world) and a secret 'neither world.' The Celtic 'good god' signifies proficiency, not morality. The 'other world' is for continued life and learning. The 'neither world,' associated with warlocks like Cei and Myrddin, is hidden and often obscured by modern demonization. Proposes a study group for Celtic Magic.

Identifies strongly with Satanic principles, tracing their roots across Aztec (Tezcatlipoca), Mayan, Egyptian (Dragon), Hebrew (Satan/Lucifer), Assyrian/Babylonian, European Black Magic, Crowley (Thelema), and LaVey (Indulgence). Proposes a threefold magical formula combining Thelema, Indulgence, and Aquino's Xeper. Advocates for an 'Order of Satan' within the Temple to evolve Satanic Black Magic, seen as the Temple's foundation.
A poem about personal transformation, the self as a vessel for the 'Flame,' the 'magic blood,' and the process of becoming both hunter and prey through Xeper.

Announces the Chaldean Pylon's transformation into the Nephren-Ka Pylon, dedicated to exploring 'blackest of mysteries' in the Pennsylvania, West Virginia, and Maryland area, referencing H.P. Lovecraft.

Introduces the Order of Xepera as an evolutionary successor to the Order of the Scarab, defining its purpose as facilitating Xeper. Xepera is described as 'the principle of being ordered in and of one's self; the neter of self-generated godly becoming.' Outlines three proficiency levels (Postulant, Scholastic, Metaphysician) and the Setian task of slaying Osiris (conventional religion) and Apep (mass media/politics) to create space for self-creation.

key_concepts.definition: The Æonic Word of Set, meaning 'to Come Into Being' or 'active self in conjunction with the psyche, conscious evolution of refined true will.' It represents the individual's process of self-creation and personal apotheosis, distinct from external cosmic order.
The process of consciously bringing forth an initiatory pattern, vision, or archetypal force into one's present reality, making it manifest and operative in one's life.
The inherent Setian quality within individuals, connecting them to Set's origins and providing the potential for unique magical power and insight, distinguishing them from the natural order.

An inner feminine nature or 'demonic/minority self' which, when integrated with the outer masculine self, leads to a state of wholeness, self-integration, and empowering polarization, as exemplified by Merlin.

The 'spirit' or 'essence' that radiates from a specific area or place. In Setian context, it refers to sites of undiluted magical power that can be consciously discovered and personally engaged with, ideally through internal ritualization rather than passive tourism.

Jungian concepts used to describe aspects of the self: 'Number 1' is the ordinary ego-self, while 'Number 2' is the archetypal, noble, ageless, and infinitely wiser self, analogous to the Setian 'Horus' (psychophysical complex) and 'Set' (core Essence/higher self) respectively.

A concept of harmony or integration between the 'Horus' (psychophysical complex) and 'Set' (core Essence/higher self) aspects of the individual, deemed essential for true Becoming and self-actualization.

Ancient Egyptian term for gods or divine forces, understood in Setian philosophy as Forms or archetypes, each with associated ideas and principles, serving as a basis for events in the physical world.

The oscillating energy within macroproxemic areas, understood through concepts like unison, octaves, harmonics, phasing, and synchronicity. It relates to the manifestation of works relevant to the current Æon and influences objective reality.

A significant advance in perception that allows an 'I' (the observer, or third component) to distinguish and know both what exists 'outside' and 'within' the self, thereby understanding the self from a point removed from itself.

key_concepts.term: Essence / Escence / Become / Being / Come Into Being
key_concepts.definition: A set of etymologically and philosophically dissected terms crucial to Setian self-creation. 'Essence' is the vital core/permanent feature; 'Escence' is the process of becoming; 'Become' is the movement towards a desired state (Xeper); 'Being' is the quality of possessing existence; 'Come Into Being' signifies the self's journey into its manifested state, giving self to self.
The eternal future, waiting to be filled with the deeds of Xeper. It is described as the realm ruled by Set-Heh, representing the eternal Set, and the destiny for those who manifest His essence.

key_concepts.term: The Three Wives of Set (Feminine Archetypes)
key_concepts.definition: Archetypal representations of the feminine in Setianism: Nepthys (goal, higher being, dream of the future), Anat (bisexual warrior goddess, foresight, preparedness), and Astarte (Scarlet Woman, perfect manifestation of the inner 'dream date'). These represent aspects of feminine power distinct from conventional models.

A practical framework for Setian engagement: 1. The world of the body (maintenance, refining); 2. The world of what is already created and conditioned (reconfiguring for happiness, power, and self-reflection); 3. The world of personal choice (objectifying fantasies); 4. The world of the Æon of Set (exploring, protecting, enhancing the Æon).

In the Order of Xepera, these represent the primary enemies of Set in modern society: Osiris symbolizes conventional religious institutions (to be 'slain once'), and Apep symbolizes mass media and politics (to be 'slain nightly').
The principle of 'being ordered in and of one's self; the neter of self-generated godly becoming.' It emphasizes self-definition and limitation by the self rather than by external cosmic order.

practical_system.description: The core system is Setian Black Magic, focused on individual self-evolution (Xeper) through conscious self-ordering, integration of disparate psychic forces (e.g., Horus/Set, fylgja), and the deliberate application of will to transform both the internal (subjective universe) and external (objective world) realities. It involves aligning one's consciousness with archetypal forces (neteru) and engaging with Æonic resonance through various magical and philosophical practices to achieve unique personal apotheosis.
tools: Conscious realization of non-natural psychic origins
Integration of polarized psychic forces (inner feminine/outer masculine)
Study and emulation of mythological archetypes (Merlin, Tezcatlipoca, Set's wives, Celtic deities)
Triadic comprehension as a perceptual tool
Understanding and manipulation of Æonic resonance
Music and sound (especially electronically-synthesized) as aural gateways and tools for creating subjective universes
Language as a formative tool (etymological dissection of magical words)
Cultural memes and media (as elements to influence or 'slay')
rituals: Remanifestation of initiatory patterns (e.g., Merlin's life)
Rituals to awaken four virtues (Knowledge, Daring, Will, Silence)
Workings on behalf of non-human creatures
Conscious creation/discovery of personal magical energy sources (Genius Loci)
Internal ritualization for public sacred sites
Slaughtering Osiris (conventional religion) and Apep (mass media/politics) through antinomian techniques (e.g., Black Masses) and specific Temple methodologies
Workings related to the 'Four Worlds' (e.g., reconfiguring environment, objectifying fantasies, protecting/enhancing the Æon)
The Rite of Embarkation for the Order of Xepera

relevant_quotes.text: Ab uno disce omnes: From one example learn about all.
We each have a fetch - a demonic or minority self, as Anton LaVey termed it.

Merlin is not blind to the fact that the Flame can diminish if it is not fed, and so he sustains his Otherworld contacts throughout his life, obtaining his vision and his power from a dark goddess, such as were beloved of the Celts.

The paradox of conventional Satanism was that the Devil was understood to be a force of nature, thus being derived from and ultimately dependent on God in some way. He may make a lot of noise, but in the final analysis he is part of the same all-inclusive machinery of the Universe/God; even his rebellion is part of God's universal scheme. Satanists, accordingly, might be able to play a good game, but ultimately the deck is stacked against them. They cannot win. - "The Prince of Darkness", Black Magic
The core or true self [...] exists as a neter and, when looking outward, sees a universe not of the works of other neteru, but of those neteru themselves.
Your ability to align your consciousness with your neter, rather than your superficial, animal, illusion of ‘self”, is Xeper.

I, Set, am my Self distinct from the Order of the Cosmos, yet am ordered in and of my Self. HarWer I was when I was once part of the Cosmos and could achieve identity only by becoming what the Cosmic order was not. By HarWer I canceled the imbalance, leaving a Void in which true Creation could take form as Set.
Xepera is the principle of being ordered in and of one's self; the neter of self-generated godly becoming.

critical_analysis.relevance: This document is highly relevant as a primary source for understanding the philosophical and practical currents within the Temple of Set in 1996. It showcases the integration of diverse magical traditions (Celtic, Mesoamerican, Jungian, Egyptian) under the umbrella of Setian philosophy, particularly the concept of Xeper. It emphasizes individual self-deification, practical application of magic in daily life ('The Four Worlds'), and addresses internal debates (Satanism vs. Setianism) and external perceptions. It provides a unique snapshot of the intellectual and magical development within a specific occult order.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Primarily intended for initiates and members of the Temple of Set, especially those interested in the deep philosophical and practical aspects of Setianism, Black Magic, and personal transformation. It assumes familiarity with Setian terminology and concepts. It is also highly relevant for scholars of modern Western esotericism and new religious movements studying the Temple of Set.
